title: Friday, 8th March 2019
bodyHTML:
11:07 am
BE11:07am

Hey.

VV75 hi
DogDay Morning all
Bluesky21 Yay!
BE11:07am

One of my favourite genres of journalism is, "I'm quitting journalism and sod you all."

rw42 That's not a genre unique to journalism.
VV75 ah, friday musings
FATDAZ Good morning all
BE11:08am

(This is Markets Live, BTW. FT Alphaville's thing with the typing.)

Soundbuy Hello
AC21 Good morning
11:08 am

Here's a pretty great addition to the canon from Sarah Gordon, the FT's formidable and invariably on-the-side-of-good business editor: https://www.ft.com...-9bee-efab61506f44

GBKrona Hola
Montesquieu I enjoyed Sarah's piece, she landed some fair punches.
Soundbuy Is she about to jump?
Manxish Happy Friday, all
BE11:10am

Do give it a read. It covers all sorts of bases and makes passing namechecks numerous CEOs, who probably won't appreciate being dropped into the narrative.

Billy hello everyone
BE11:10am

Use discretion before heading into the comment box though, because this kind of thing is going on:

11:10 am

{Sigh}

Bluesky21 "The lower class"?
VV75 GVC CEO and Chairman dumping their share, but don't worry they are staying!
Curious I liked the line "in fact most companies are run pretty badly"entirely unrelated I see Mike Ashley is trying to chuck out debenham's board
BE11:12am

Businesses aren't owned by shareholders, directors' main commitment isn't to deliver value to them, and greed as a driving force for good is at best unproven.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

As for the stuff about lower classes and brooding hens, jeez.

BE11:12am

Anyway.

undefined

Kenny Alexander and Lee Feldman, CEO and Chairman respectively, slotting three quarters of their shareholdings at 666p.

11:14 am

It doesn't look a great signal, particularly given the shares were more than £11 in August.

BE11:15am

........ and we have all sorts of noise around regarding tougher rules on credit card wagers and that kind of thing, and you have downgrades ticking through constantly for the US gold rush.

BE11:16am

Plus you have Kenny saying on Tuesday that all was well, sunlit uplands from here, etc.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Perhaps he just needed £13.7m in a hurry.

Soundbuy 666 - hmmmm..........

Sector down as a result, in part on worries about what might come in next week's spring budget.

(@Marktime: farewell.)

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Good morning ship mates!
BE11:18am

......... though of course, if industry had been consulted on potential government legislation and directors sold before that becoming public, that would be insider trading.

Flaneur Bryce Elder - Exuding jaded cynicism so you dont have to. ™And I, for one, thank you.
11:19 am
BE11:19am

A government minister selling on potential government legislation is fine, though. As far as anyone can work out.

FATDAZ @BE when he made those sunny uplands comments should he have had to disclose his intentions to sell stock ...... conflict of interest there surely
BE11:19am

Let's back into some sellside saying, "ooh, bad optics."

BE11:19am

Barclays:

11:19 am
BE11:20am

As with any significant selling by management, we have no doubt that there are understandable reasons for the sale; not least in the case of Mr. Alexander, we suspect a significant portion of his wealth was tied up in GVC stock (even after the selling, we think Mr. Alexander is likely to own more of his company than many other CEOs in the sector). That said, there is rarely a good time to sell shares as it is almost always seen as a negative signal. We would flag that both Mr. Alexander and Mr. Feldman have had large personal shareholdings in GVC for a long time and both will continue to even after the significant selling of GVC stock. In the statement today, Mr. Alexander says he is fully committed for the long term and has a ‘current plan that will take 3 years to accomplish.’ We flag that this selling comes after a period of a significant de-rating for both GVC and the sector and comes so soon after Mr. Alexander’s bullish outlook at FY18 results on Tuesday. We continue to think that GVC could deliver upgrades to estimates over the next 12 months and we view the shares as relatively cheap. That being said, this news is likely to met with concern by some shareholders and non-shareholders alike and coupled with the significant regulatory pressure that the sector is under, we doubt this will do anything to change investor sentiment towards the sector (which remains at multi-year lows in our view).

Flaneur Unless BE says otherwise I'd like to hold forth on something I noticed recently....
Viking1 Norway saying goodbye to Oil
Flaneur ...its tangential to the betting industry.
BE11:21am

(@Fatdaz: .... maybe? Though maybe you're into a Gordon Brown selling gold conundrum.)

BE11:21am

marktime A clumsy reference to colour? Fair enough, it is your gme

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Unhelpful timing. Immediately after a very upbeat finals presentation that focused on growth prospects, and ahead of a CMD on 16 May, the timing may mean investorschoose to disregard much of the positive commentary.
Plan. The statement points to a three-year plan that may emerge in the CMD.
Valuation: FY20E: 12.0% FCF yield, 8.3x PE6.7x EV/EBITDA. Our 1,100p PT is DCFbased.
JEF view. The upbeat finals and greater than £11 share price last year will sit uncomfortablywith these share sales. A material short-term negative, with de-rating likely to linger for some time.

Flaneur Its about my kids and the games they play... some of them have 'trading' elements. I'd like to see if anyone else notices this.

(@Flaneur: the stage is yours. The bit on the right at least.)

Bull/bear NSF? Interesting boardroom shenanigans...!
Flaneur Firstly theres the 'straight swap' component; they swap a magic sword for a super shield... or somesuch.

Story on Norway exiting oil is here: https://www.ft.com...-5bbd-af33dc531acb

Flaneur (@BE ty, appreciated.)Each of these items has a value in either in-game currency, unique power or rarity. This seems to imbue 'value'.
BE11:24am

Norway’s $1tn oil fund should sell out of upstream oil and gas shares, the country’s government has recommended, in a move that will send shockwaves through the energy sector.

The world’s largest sovereign wealth fund, which owns about $37bn in oil and gas shares, should sell out of companies that solely explore and produce oil and gas in a bid to reduce the risk to the Norwegian economy, according to the country’s finance minister.

“The goal is to make our collective wealth less vulnerable to a lasting fall in oil prices,” said Siv Jensen, finance minister of western Europe’s largest petroleum producer.

Flaneur Winning a race or whatever earns a chest with some random reward.

Curious though it does suggest they think the oil price is going to fall & stay low. Would be interesting to know what level they expect the price to stabilise at

Want JPMorgan on Saga? It seems to be doing some damage.

Saga PLC (SAGA:LSE): Last: 112.53, down 10.27 (-8.36%), High: 117.20, Low: 110.80, Volume: 2.32m
BE11:32am

Saga, in our view, faces margin pressure across its broking business, as
competitive conditions continue to weigh on industry profitability. Several
of the larger UK motor players have reported in the past week and all have
described industry pricing that is failing to keep pace with claims inflation.
Given that Saga is seeking to return to policy growth after many years of
declines, this is an unhelpful backdrop, we believe, while travel may also
be seeing pressure due to Brexit uncertainty. Saga is taking on a significant
amount of new debt in the next two years to fund its two new cruise ships
and, in our view, remaining below 3.0x at the leverage peak looks
increasingly challenging. Thus, we see little scope for a re-rating currently,
as any further pressure could raise the question of dividend sustainability.
We reduce our estimates, which remain below consensus, by 2%/4%
for FY20/21, lowering our TP to 120p and moving to an UW rating.

11:33 am

Saga, to remind, is growing its cruise business five-fold

Flaneur Other 'games' were scratchcard-style affairs.These sites are clearly introducing underage children to the mechanics, imagery and environment of FOBTs.How is this legal - its not gambling, per say, but it clearly is if you see what I mean...This is definitely one for Izzy, no? Go get that Pulitzer!

rw42 Nearly all mobile games i've seen include some elements of daily rewards which function as a window to an element of gambling - daily chests with random rewards where you can buy more chests, or give you currency to buy said chests. It's all designed to cultivate impatience imo - wait 5 days for this bunch of pixels to be built so you can slay that bunch of pixels, or you can pay a low sum to complete it now!Considering the amount of attention paid to actual gambling, sooner or later they'll be looking at how companies push on the minds of people playing games and start to think it sounds a little exploitative!

Meaning leverage peaks at 3.1x EBITDA at FY21, according to Caz.

While the strong cash flow profile of the shops should allow this to fall
quickly after this point, we do not currently see a large amount of
flexibility, while a further deterioration in market conditions could start
to pose questions about dividend sustainability. An adverse outcome
from the FCA market study, in particular, could be a risk we believe.

Fortnite for instance has tweaked their model to be more transparent after a umber of legal challenges.I recommend RPS as a relatively mature start point for discussions on the subject https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2019/03/02/lawsuit-claims-fortnites-random-loot-boxes-were-deceptive/

It's one of the subjects where Wikipedia is a very good source, because the people who write Wikipedia are dorks deeply involved in the mechanics of this stuff: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loot_box

rw42 There was a brilliant article i read a few months back which explained how the most profitable football game was one where you could buy loot crates to collect players - it's where this model of X thing takes 20 cards to unlock, with a chance of each chest containing a few cards. Once one company does it and it's seen how profitable/addictive it is, the pressure is on for everyone to do it!

11:42 am

Here are the blob notes via Numis.

Viking1 Bodycote 8% post results ?
BE11:43am

Cash offer from Berry. Ahead of the PUSU deadline of 13th March 2019, Berry Global Group has made a cash offer of 793p/share for RPC Group. The offer values the company at £3.34bn, and represents a premium of 16% to the closing price on the last business day prior to the start of the Offer Period,
● Premium to Apollo Offer. Importantly, today's offer from Berry is 11p higher than the final recommended offer that has already been made by Apollo Capital Management, equating to a small premium to that offer of 1.4%.
● Recommended by management. In light of today’s news, management confirm that they have withdrawn their recommendation for the offer from Apollo and have adjourned the shareholder meetings scheduled for 20 March 2019 to consider the Apollo Offer. Further, management have outlined that they intend to unanimously recommend the offer from Berry Global.
● Implied valuation. Based on our current estimates for RPC Group, the implied takeout multiples include a 2019 P/E of 10.8x, falling to 10x for 2020, and a 2019 EV/EBITDA multiple of 7.3x, falling to 6.8x based on 2020 estimates.

TB @BE you mentioned in today’s paper a potential transaction for ULVR!
BE11:44am

And a bit of context from Olivetree .....

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Even though the discussion of the last few weeks was centred around the lack of price tension (given Apollo’s “final” nature), it will come as a small surprise to see the target flip its recommendation for such a small increment – at the margin Berry is very so slightly less deliverable than Apollo so it had been envisaged that Berry would pay something slightly in excess of 800p.

The market will now focus on the IRR nature of this transaction, it is hard to see there being any further complications – either positive or negative. We cover the anti-trust of a Berry/RPC combination below, our stance has always been that it is manageable. At this stage of a straightforward UK process one tends to model c4 months to completion – Berry guides to “early Q3”, suggesting they too see the antitrust as being simple to achieve. Presumably the small magnitude of the bump shows us that RPC management is also convinced that there are no meaningful antitrust concerns to the Berry offer either. Note the language too in this morning’s statement, “Berry Bidco understands that its anti-trust requirements are the same as those required under the Apollo Offer and, based on extensive work so far, it anticipates that the timeline for completion of its transaction will be very close to Apollo's timeline.” Note that it does need Chinese approval.

BE11:45am

The thing I'd note here is that Berry's going to be extremely levered post this. And it's buying a bunch of assets collected in a rollup that would seem to have variable value.

BE11:46am

I'm not expecting a warm response from Berry shareholders.

In a straight takeover, rather than a merger like the one Kraft sort-of proposed two years ago, Unilever would also be in a prime position to call the shots, and export its culture and management approach – one where growth is not sacrificed at the altar of cost savings. Nonetheless, there would be copious synergies to harvest from combining overlapping functions, from corporate overheads to global procurement.

Nick Bubb can pick up the story from here ........

marktime We are not missing BHS and we would not miss Debenhams so long as there is a Marks and Sparks, so why save it
BE11:54am

At the unholy time of 6.16pm last night, Sports Direct announced the bombshell that it is requisitioning an EGM to vote most of the Directors off the Board and install “Mad” Mike Ashley as the boss of the embattled Debenhams business. Extraordinarily, #MadMike is even prepared to step down as CEO at Sports Direct to indulge his new-found obsession with department store retailing, with Chris Wootton (who is currently Sports Direct's deputy CFO) ready to take over at the helm! Debenhams has 21 days to respond and it then has to give 28 days’ notice, so a meeting at the end of April looks on the cards, which may or may not fit with Debenhams’ timetable for a big funding exercise and the mooted CVA. What #MadMike thinks of a CVA plan is not clear, but presumably he is unhappy at the thought of his c30% stake in Debenhams being heavily diluted by a debt-for-equity swap…This saga will run and run and the only thing that is clear is that Sports Direct shareholders will be alarmed at this massive distraction for the business…

DJ Random comment: As much as I love the FT, anyone else unimpressed with this article? https://www.ft.com/content/8991bf9a-40cd-11e9-9bee-efab61506f44

FY18 results: sales of £730m came inline with MSe and consensus, EBITA of
£138m was 1% below MSe but 2% ahead of consensus, with margins of 19%
10bps below MSe but 40bps above consensus, EPS of 56p, 2% ahead of MSe
and 5% above consensus (tax rate 21.7% vs MSe 24.5%). Bodycote also
announced a special dividend of 20p.
End markets: Civil Aviation +8%, General Industrial +6%, Energy +13%, Auto +7%.
2019 outlook: "While we are conscious of the global macro-economic backdrop, we
have entered 2019 well positioned and at this early point in the year, our
expectations for 2019 remain unchanged".
Conclusion: An in-line sales print and a 2% EBITA beat. We expect minimal
changes to current consensus expectations.
